Award.AwardTitle: Full-Scale Development: Designing Our World: A Community Envisioning Girls as Engineers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This full-scale project addresses the need for more youth, especially girls, to pursue an interest in engineering and eventually fill a critical workforce need. The project leverages museum-based exhibits, girls' activity groups, and social media to enhance participants' engineering-related interests and identities. The project includes the following bilingual deliverables:

1. Creative Solutions programming will engage girls in group oriented engineering activities at partner community-based organizations, where the activities highlight altruistic, personally relevant, and social aspects of engineering. Existing community groups will use the activities in their regular meeting structure. Visits to the museum exhibits, titled Design Your World will reinforce messages.

2. Design Your World Exhibits will serve as a community hub at two ISE institutions (Oregon Museum of Science and Industry and the Hatfield Marine Science Center). They will leverage existing NSF-funded Engineer It! (DRL-9803989) exhibits redesigned to attract, engage, and mobilize a more diverse population by showcasing altruistic, personally relevant, and social aspects of engineering.

3. Digital engagement through targeted use of social media will complement program and exhibit content and be an online portal for groups engaged in the project.

4. A community action group (CAG) will provide professional development opportunities to stakeholders interested in girls' STEM identity (e.g. parents, STEM-based business professionals) to promote effective engineering messaging throughout the community and engage them in supporting project participants.

5. Longitudinal research will explore how girls construct and negotiate engineering-related identities through discourse across the project activities and over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Designing Our World (DOW) was to empower and promote youths’, especially girls’, pursuit of engineering careers by cultivating networks of community stakeholders and engaging girls with experiences that illuminated the social, personally relevant, and altruistic nature of engineering to support girls’ engineering identity formation, showing girls and their peers the various ways in which the engineering process relates to their lives and to potential careers. This contributes to broader impact by attracting underrepresented groups, including girls aged 9-14 to the field of engineering, helping to fill a gap in the engineering workforce.

At the center of this project were the partnerships with Adelante Mujeres, Girls Inc. of the Pacific Northwest, Boys and Girls Club of Portland, and Hatfield Marine Science Center. They were key in co-creating after school experiences and providing feedback and content for engineering-related group activities, an engineering exhibit at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, and professional development offered to adult informal STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) educators.

Working with a research advisory committee, the DOW research team developed a model to help explain how the STEM identities of youth develop within informal engineering programs. This model provides an important foundation for future research on STEM identity development and fills a critical gap in the literature related to understanding more dynamic, context-specific aspects of identity. The framework has been an important way to incorporate research findings into practice and has been used as a professional development tool to highlight the value of reflective practice in program development and delivery. The model has been shared through a variety of professional publications and has informed the development of an identity reflection tool for educators. The reflection tool is designed to help educators understand youth identity negotiation in their own programs and reflect on ways that program design and facilitation strategies might support or hinder STEM identity development for participants.

 DOW contributed to intellectual merit by generating relevant knowledge for practitioners and providing free access to the DOW activities through https://omsi.edu/educator-resources. These activities led to the creation of professional development curriculum for informal science educators, a symposium for informal education professionals, and the facilitation of the professional development curriculum to over 12 organizations across the US.  

This project highlighted the ways in which engineering careers and engineering design thinking can be altruistic, personally relevant, and social; empowering adult stakeholders to support girls and people of color in pursuing engineering careers. By fostering a sense of self-efficacy in engineering design thinking and a positive attitude toward engineering careers, the project provided support for girls’ engineering identity formation, showing girls and their peers the various ways in which the engineering process relates to their lives and to potential careers.
